TextEquiv.Unicode: The COUNTRY JOURNAL: OR, THE CRAFTSMAN.

ILLIAM the id 1, iled the Con‐ queror, certainly could not have that Appellation from the winning one only Battle ; for his Viory over Harold, and the taking of Dover, were his only military Exploits in England, before he was crown'd ; and theſe, had not the Cabals of the Clergy prevented the Degns of Men zealous for their Country , he had found would rather have proved Snares, by animating him to puſh his Purſuits, as he would have had freſh Armies to encounter in an Enemy's Country, where he might have lo his own, had not the Engliſh refuſed to hazard a ſecond Battle. I ſay, when one conders the Situation of that Prince, his Viory had proved rather a Snare than an Advantage, but for the Power of the Clergy ; and have ſhewn his Undertaking as raſh, as by the Intervention of the Churchmen, it proved fortunate. Wherefore, I am inclined to believe this Appellation of Conqueror was rather given him by the Engliſh, from the Manner of his treating his new Subjes. At ﬁr he was tender of provoking them, exhorting his great Oﬃcers to treat them with Moderation, and ſeverely puniſhing the Subalterns and Soldiers who gave them any ju Grounds of Complaint ; but this did not prevent his Jealoues, and his taking all neceary Precautions to ſecure his Acquili tion. He immediately rewarded the Heads of his Fol‑ lowers out of Harold's Treaſures, garriſon'd rong Towns, and carry'd into Normandy ſeveral of the Engliſh No‑ bility.

Though William aﬀeed to begin his Reign with Le‑ nity, it was not long before the Engliſh were made ſen‑ ble, by his Regents, whom he left, on returning to Normandy, that they were deem'd a conquer'd People ; for theſe Regents either abuſed their Authority, to enrich themſelves and Creatures, or follow'd the Orders William had given them, to provoke the Engliſh to rebel, that he might have ah Opportunity to puniſh and empoveriſh them ; rengthen himſelf, by dividing their Eates among his Normans, and, farther, by their Spoils, to diſcharge the heavy Debt he had contraed for his Expedition, which he had no Way to pay oﬀ, but by ripping the Engliſh. The Inſults which the Conquer'd daily ſuﬀer'd ; the King's Jealouſy, increaſed by two fruitleſs Attempts to ſhake oﬀ the Norman Yoke ; his Wants and avaritious Temper, could not but breed ill Blood between him and his Subjes of England, whoſe Murmurings made him reſolve to eabliſh the Authority he had gain'd, by what‑ ever Means, whether conſonant or not with Juice ; whe‑ ther agreeable or not to the People, and by the Revival of Dane‐gelt, which was exaed with the utmo Rigour, reminded them of their former Miſeries under the Ty‑ ranny of that Nation. This, and other Methods to raiſe Money, occaon'd Revolts ; Revolts, Severities. The Normans were carreſs'd , and the Engliſh little better treated than Slaves. Væ Viis. The Po�ts of Honour and Proﬁ�, with the Eates of the latter, were given to the former ; the Clergy, who had, we may ſay, given him the Crown, were not exempted. The King cancell'd the Immunities granted them by his Predeceors ; Soldiers were quarter'd upon their Monalleries , which were plunder'd of their Money and Plate ; their Abbots, nay, and Biſhops were depoſed, to make Room for Normans. But what was yet a greater Proof of their Slavery, the innocent Engliſh were puniſh'd for the Crimes of the Nor‑ mans, and were alſo turn'd out of their Dwellings, their Churches and Villages demoliſh'd, to become a Receptacle for Bealls. In a Word, he was jealous of, hated, deſ‑ piſed the Engliſh, and treated them with the greate Se‑ verity, putting out their Eyes, cutting oﬀ their Hands and Feet, arving them to Death, and impriſoning them for Life ; uſual Puniſhments for ſmall Crimes. Yet he obtain'd the Crown rather by the Gift of the People, in‑ uenced by the Clergy, than by Force of Arms ; though 'tis not impoble he might deem their Submion the Eﬀe of Cowardice, and from thence hold them as Ob‐ jes of Contempt ; think he had no Obligation to a People whoſe Fears, alone, had given him Poeon of the Throne, and alſo, for that Reaſon, judge it his Right of Conque.

It may be ſaid, that this Treatment was no more than what the Engliſh merited for their Folly, in not having made Terms on their Submion. Though we ﬁnd not what Terms the Clergy made, yet we may conclude that they ined on ſome, eſpecially for themſelves. But did

this avail them any thing, when William was in Poeſ‑ on of the Kingdom ? Conditions which Sovereigns make with their Subjes are not always regarded by the former, and who, among the latter, dare undertake to ex� the Obſervance of them, though violated in the mo ﬂagrant Manner ? Such a Step would be a Rebellion, and he who took it, together with his Adherents, would undergo the Fate of Traitors, if they had not Power to oblige the Prince to do them Juice ; and when that has been the Caſe, they have commonly exceeded the Bounds of their ﬁr Pretenons ; ſhewn as little Regard for their Allegiance as the Sovereign had for his Engagements : and were as unju in encroaching on the Prerogatives of the Crown, as the Monarch had been in his Endeavours to extend them over the Privileges and Liberties of the People. The Power the Barons formerly had, enabled them to exa of their Kings the Performance of Conditions, but that Power did not exi in the Time of the Conqueror, and the Struggles the Engliſh made in his Time only increaſed the Weight of their Burden, and riveted their Fetters. A King who has a anding Army, and has any Regard to the Conditions on which he received the Crown, gives a rare Example of Juice and Moderation ; but ſhould he treat them as a weak Impotion, how would the People be redreſs'd ? Their Murmurs might (if ever they came to his Ears) acquaint him with their Diſcontent, but, at the ſame time, they would proclaim their Weakneſs, excite his Contempt, awake his Vigilance ; occaon his Diﬃ‑ dence, and increaſe their Misfortunes, by making them purchaſe, at a dearer Rate, the Chains he degn'd them. We have but one Inance of a anding Army generouy refung to be made the Inruments for enaving their Country. Whereſore, the Engliſh were guilty of a Folly in being inﬂuenced by the Clergy, and in not exerting themſelves to oppoſe the Invader ; not in negleing to make Terms with him on their Submion. By Condi‑ tions on the Marriage of Queen Mary with Philip of Spain, we were not any Way to be involved in the War that Prince had with France ; and what did this avail us ? The Queen broke it, and we lo Calais. Did King James the 2d a as if he thought himſelf bound to keep any Conditions with his People ? It is true, we were mira‑ culouy ſaved from the fatal Conſequences of the Meaſures he purſued ; but let me aſk, if 'tis probable that he would have taken the Steps he did, had he not had an Army ? Could the People expe that Army would deſert him ? In caſe they had not, could the Prince of Orange, with the few Troops he landed, have eﬀeed the glorious Re‑ volution ? And if he had been obliged to re‐embark, would not the very Men, whoſe Succeſs gave them the Appella‑ tion of Deliverers of their Country, been igmatized with that of Traitors to their King ? I have ſaid thus much, to ſhew, ﬁr, that the Engliſh were guilty of no Over‐ ght in negleing to demand Conditions, but in tamely ſubmitting to receive the Norman Yoke, and, next, in endeavouring to ſhake it oﬀ, when the Power of the Con‑ queror ought to have taken from them all Hopes of ſuc‑ ceeding, and have convinced them that their Eﬀorts mu necearily tend to their Ruin. They ought to have praiſed the Dorine of the Tories, and, by a pave Obedience, quietly have acquieſced in theſe Misfortunes which were the Eﬀes of their Folly ; a Dorine which Prudence preaches, but which, however, the Engliſh, of whatever Denomination, have not been found very ready to lien to, but when they had no other Remedy.

I allow the ſeeing of Strangers, Subjes of a Province of France, prefer'd to the Engliſh ; to ſee theſe Strangers look down with Contempt upon them ; themſelves turn'd out of Po�ls and of their Ellates, to make Koom for Nor‑ mans, mu be very galling ; but when we conder that they brought theſe Inſults, and other Misſortunes, upon themſelves, by inconderately bowing their Necks to re‑ ceive the Yoke of a ſoreign Prince, we can ſcarce aord our Pity to the Calamities they experienced. The Spend‑ thrift, who, by his inconderate Management, ru�s through his Patrimony, and is reduced to Want, meets with more to reproach his Folly than to commiſerate his Suﬀerings ; nay, the very Perſons who proﬁ�ed by the Extravagance of the Squire will inſult the Miſeries of the Beggar ; and could the Engliſh imagine that the Normans, who were enrich'd by the Folly of a free People, would not inſult the Wretchedneſs of their Slavery ; for we can call their Suﬀerings no other ?. But to return to Condi‑ tions between Prince and People.

Let us ſuppoſe what our Anceors ſuſfer'd was our own Caſe, which it never can be under the Dominion of a Prince of Engliſh Blood, (though a Foreigner) who has gain'd the Hearts of his People, by his Wi�dom, Juice, Moderation and Bravery ; but, I ſay, let us ſuppoſe that

he could be capable of aweing us into a ﬂaviſh Submion, by making the Conﬁdence we have repoſed in him the Means of doing it ; exa what Sums he pleaſed ; make his Army his Colleors ; revive the Corv�e�feu, corruptly the Curfew, and, on our murmuring, turn the Engliſh not only out of their Pos but Ellates, and ſubitute H—ns ; treat the Engliſh with Contempt, and mention them with Hatred ; that we were diinguiſh'd, by even the meane Servants among the H—ns, as a mo deſpicable People, ﬁt only to be employ'd under them in the mo ſervile Oﬃces, and, if carry'd into the Field, proper only to receive the ﬁr Fire of the Enemy, placed as Screens, and dellined to be Food for Gunpowder, and to ﬁll up Ditches, as Sir John Falaﬀ ſays, could we be tax'd with Want of having made our Conditions ? It is certain we could not, and as certain, that we owe the Blengs we now enjoy under his Majey, to his great Wiſdom, Juice and Moderation, not to our Precaution. For the Experience we have had of his Royal Virtues wrought on us to inve him with the Power to treat us as the Conqueror did our Anceors. But we had a Security which can never fail us ; the Regard his M—y has to his own Honour, and that Uprightneſs obſervable in all his Aiors. It is true, ſome of the Conditions on which the Crown was transfer'd from the next immediate Suc‑ ceor to his illurious Houſe, have, by the Wiſdom of P——t, been ſet ade ; but this is a rong Proof that, notwithllanding we had entrulled him with a Power not to want their Conſent, his Majey would (and, we may be ſatisfy'd, always will) ſquare his Aions by the Laws, and not attempt any thing again the Rights and Privileges of the Engliſh. If he has a Tenderneſs for his native Country, 'tis a laudable Virtue, bede, can no way aﬀe us. Was it a Condition, when the Crown was oﬀer'd to the illuricus Houſe, that they ſhould ca oﬀ their H—n Subjes, on the receiving the Engliſh under their Proteion ; or that, in becoming the Fathers of ours, they ſhould no longer be the Parents of their own Country ? I dare ſay, our Tender of the Engliſh Diadem, accompany'd with ſuch a Condition, would have been rejeed with the greate Scorn and indignation. If fome H—ns h�ve enrich'd themſelves in England, can any ſay it was by Violence ? Have they not, in��ead of inſult‐ ing the Engliſh, done them all friendly Oﬃces ; employ'd their Credit with their Royal Maer, to procure ſuch as have apply'd to them, Pos, &c ? If ſuch Engliſh, who have owed their Preferment to their Interpotion, have made them grateful Acknowledgments, can they be tax'd with Exaions ? Was not what they received lawfully their own ? If they were better Occonomis than we ge‑ nerally are, and took home with them what they ſaved, was it unju or unnatural ? None can ſay that they have been put into Pos of Tru or Prot, and ſuppoſe ſome of them have been quarter'd upon ſuch Engliſh as accepted Places on that Condition, can they, who joyfully em‑ braced the Oﬀer, murmur, and can this aﬀe another Perſon ? But there, poilibly, is no Ground to make this Suppotion, and, if it was a known Fa, his M—y ſurely may be as well irdulged in gratiſying ſome of his foreign Servants, eſpecially when it is with ſuch Tender‑ neſs and Regard to cur Laws, as a M——r, who ſhall give ſuch Places to his Livery Servants, as Gentlemen of Birth have thought themſelves happy to ſerve as their Deputies. I have heard that a certain Baronet was Deputy to a Footman, for little more than the fourth Part of the Revenue, and that the Son of this very Footman is pro‑ vided with a handſome Po in the C——ms. But had his M——y gratify'd his G———n Servants with Pos in the Government, condering the many Blengs we have enjoy'd, nce the A———n, could it be Ground of Diſcontent with any but the mo ungrateful of the Na‐ tion ? And condering, again, the Power with which the Nation has invelled h��, from an Experience of his Wiſdom and Juice, could any Perſon dare (if not de‐ pending on his Moderation) to ſay , Why do thou ſo ? Every thing is be known by its contrary ; wherefore, a View of the Life of William the Conqueror, and of his lace and preſent M——y, whoſe Power is not inferior to that of the Normans ; a Reeion on the Miſeries the Engliſh ſuﬀer'd under the one, and the Advantages they enjoy under the other, will ſet his M——y's Goodneſs, and our Happineſs, in a ju Point of Light. Nay, ſuch a Compariſon would make us acknowledge, that we are inﬁnitely obliged to his Equity, in being allow'd to enjoy thoſe Rights and Privileges which we claim as our Birth‐ right, did we owe nothing elle to the paternal Care of � R——l and I ——s Houſe.
Wherefore, on the whole, I c����ude, that all Cond�‑ tions which the Sun���� make, ��ch a Prince who has ����
By CALEB D'ANVERS, of GRAY'S‐INN, Eſq;
Printed for W. WARD, at the Black Lion in Ruel‐Street, Covent‐Garden.
